list.title: How to Write an Open Source JavaScript Library
list.description:
Publishing a JavaScript library for public use requires some extra steps. You need to think about how people will use the library. From end users, to contributors your library now has a variety of people outside of yourself potentially making use of the code that you've released into the wild.

From Github and npm, to releasing beta versions, semantic versioning, code coverage, continuous integration, and providing your library with a solid set of unit tests, there are a ton of things to learn.

This series will guide you through a set of steps to publish a JavaScript open source library.

You might also enjoy [this article about contributing to open source](https://egghead.io/articles/get-started-contributing-to-javascript-open-source).

lessons.title: Introduction to How to Write an Open Source JavaScript Library
lessons.summary: This is an introduction to the "How to Write a JavaScript Library" in which the scope of the series is presented. You will learn everything you need to know to create a library for JavaScript: set up the [GitHub](https://github.com) repo, publish a module to [npm](https://www.npmjs.com/), set up a test suite with code coverage reporting (using [Karma](http://karma-runner.github.io/), [Mocha](http://mochajs.org/), and [Chai](http://chaijs.com/)), add continuous integration, add ES6 (ES2015) with [Babel](http://babeljs.io/), configure [Webpack](http://webpack.github.io/), and distribute the library as a ["Universal JavaScript"](https://medium.com/@mjackson/universal-javascript-4761051b7ae9) (a.k.a. "Isomorphic JavaScript") module (consumable by both the browser and node).

instructor.bio: Kent C. Dodds is a JavaScript developer currently working at [PayPal](https://www.paypal.com/) during the day, and on several side and [open source projects](http://github.com/kentcdodds) at night (and early in the morning sometimes). Kent's favorite things include: coding, talking about coding, speaking at meetups and conferences, and spending time with his wife and two kids.
instructor.bio_short: a JavaScript developer who likes open source and teaching.

Creating the library and adding dependencies
Releasing a new version to npm
Setting up Unit Testing with Mocha and Chai
Unit Testing with Mocha and Chai
Committing a new feature with commitizen

Adding code coverage recording with Istanbul
Adding ES6 Support to Tests using Mocha and Babel
Add a browser build to an npm module

lessons.title: Setting up GitHub
lessons.summary: In this lesson, you'll learn how to set up a GitHub account, create a new GitHub repository, and connect your local project with that new repository so you have a place to store and collaborate on your library code.

lessons.title: Configuring npm and creating a package.json
lessons.summary: In this lesson, you'll learn how to set up your machine to publish to [npm](https://www.npmjs.com/) so people can install your library. You'll configure some helpful defaults and use those to create a `package.json` file for your project using `npm init`.

lessons.title: Creating the library and adding dependencies
lessons.summary: Don't reinvent the wheel. We're creating a great library here, but we don't have to write every line of code. Learn how to depend on other libraries while creating your own in this lesson.

lessons.title: Releasing a version to GitHub
lessons.summary: Now that you've released your module to `npm`, it's time to learn how to associate that release with a particular commit on GitHub. In this lesson learn how to create a tag using `git tag` and then how to associate that with a release on GitHub.

lessons.title: Releasing a new version to npm
lessons.summary: When you want to add a new feature, fix a bug, or push out a breaking API change, you need to take Semantic Versioning into account. In this lesson, learn what each number means as well as how to push out a new version of your library.

lessons.title: Publishing a beta version
lessons.summary: Sometimes you're not quite ready to release a full on version of your open source library to npm. In this lesson, learn how to publish a beta version so people can try it out without tampering with anyone else using your library.

lessons.title: Unit Testing with Mocha and Chai
lessons.summary: Now that you've got everything set up with mocha and chai, it's time to actually write tests. In this lesson you'll learn how to use `describe` and `it` to outline your tests and make sure you don't break your library in the future.

lessons.title: Automating Releases with semantic-release
lessons.summary: There are so many repeated steps when releasing a new version of a library. The tool semantic-release automates this process by pushing off the responsibility of your releases to continuous integration. Trust us, this will change your workflow for the better.

instructor.bio: Kent C. Dodds is a JavaScript developer currently working at [PayPal](https://www.paypal.com/) during the day, and on several side and [open source projects](http://github.com/kentcdodds) at night (and early in the morning sometimes). Kent's favorite things include: coding, talking about coding, speaking at meetups and conferences, and spending time with his wife and two kids.

series.title: How to Write an Open Source JavaScript Library
series.description:
Publishing a JavaScript library for public use requires some extra steps. You need to think about how people will use the library. From end users, to contributors your library now has a variety of people outside of yourself potentially making use of the code that you've released into the wild.

From Github and npm, to releasing beta versions, semantic versioning, code coverage, continuous integration, and providing your library with a solid set of unit tests, there are a ton of things to learn.

This series will guide you through a set of steps to publish a JavaScript open source library.

You might also enjoy [this article about contributing to open source](https://egghead.io/articles/get-started-contributing-to-javascript-open-source).

instructor.bio: Kent C. Dodds is a JavaScript developer currently working at [PayPal](https://www.paypal.com/) during the day, and on several side and [open source projects](http://github.com/kentcdodds) at night (and early in the morning sometimes). Kent's favorite things include: coding, talking about coding, speaking at meetups and conferences, and spending time with his wife and two kids.
instructor.bio_short: a JavaScript developer who likes open source and teaching.

lessons.title: Automatically running tests before commits with ghooks
lessons.summary: Wouldn't it be nice if everyone ran the tests before committing code? With ghooks, you can automatically add a githook when dependencies are installed which will allow you to define common scripts to be run at various points during git actions (like committing). In this lesson, we'll add a githook for running the tests before we commit code to make sure we don't commit anything that breaks the tests.

Dodds is a JavaScript developer currently working at [PayPal](https://www.paypal.com/) during the day, and on several side and [open source projects](http://github.com/kentcdodds) at night (and early in the morning sometimes). lessons.title: Limit Built Branches on Travis
lessons.summary: By default, Travis will build all branches, tags, and Pull Requests. Because we're building our master branch before we release, we don't need Travis building our releases. Also, we don't care to have Travis build all the branches. So we're going to limit Travis to only build our master branch and Pull Requests by configuring travis via our `.travis.yml` file.

lessons.title: Add a browser build to an npm module
lessons.summary: Currently, our library is being distributed as a CommonJS module, but we should support the browser as well. In this lesson, we're going to use [`webpack`](http://webpack.github.io/) to create a [`UMD`](https://github.com/umdjs/umd) (Universal Module Definition) build of our module so users can consume it in a browser.

instructor.bio: Kent C. Dodds is a JavaScript developer currently working at [PayPal](https://www.paypal.com/) during the day, and on several side and [open source projects](http://github.com/kentcdodds) at night (and early in the morning sometimes). Kent's favorite things include: coding, talking about coding, speaking at meetups and conferences, and spending time with his wife and two kids.
instructor.bio_short: a JavaScript developer who likes open source and teaching.

series.title: How to Write an Open Source JavaScript Library
series.description:
Publishing a JavaScript library for public use requires some extra steps. You need to think about how people will use the library. From end users, to contributors your library now has a variety of people outside of yourself potentially making use of the code that you've released into the wild.

From Github and npm, to releasing beta versions, semantic versioning, code coverage, continuous integration, and providing your library with a solid set of unit tests, there are a ton of things to learn.

This series will guide you through a set of steps to publish a JavaScript open source library.

You might also enjoy [this article about contributing to open source](https://egghead.io/articles/get-started-contributing-to-javascript-open-source).

instructor.bio: Kent C. Dodds is a JavaScript developer currently working at [PayPal](https://www.paypal.com/) during the day, and on several side and [open source projects](http://github.com/kentcdodds) at night (and early in the morning sometimes). Kent's favorite things include: coding, talking about coding, speaking at meetups and conferences, and spending time with his wife and two kids.
instructor.bio_short: a JavaScript developer who likes open source and teaching.
